The salt flats in Salar de Uyuni, Bolivia, are the largest in the world and contain 50-70% of the world’s lithium reserves Joel Santos/Barcroft Images Thursday 23 February 2017 09.42 GMT The salt flats are the legacy of a prehistoric lake that went dry, leaving behind the salt crust The salt flats are at an altitude of 3,565 metres above sea level They are largest in the world and cover 10,582 sq km In dry season the salt flats are completely covered in salt, and in the wet season they are covered with a thin sheet of water When there is a thin sheet of water, the sky is reflected in the brine The flats are used for calibrating the distance measurement equipment of satellites as they are such a large and stable surface They are the breeding ground for several species of flamingoes (not pictured) Crystallised salt across the vast expanse Sunset over the salt flats An incoming storm cloud An antique train cemetery just outside Uyuni. The railway was built towards the end of 19th century and mainly used by mining companies until its collapse in the 1940s One of the photographer’s travelling companions rests atop their jeep on the salt flats The photographer takes a self-portrait as he leaps into the air
